title: What is a network?
subject: CN
answer: A network is an interconnected system of devices such as computers and peripherals that can communicate and share data over communication channels like cables or wireless media.

title: Why are computer networks important?
subject: CN
answer: Computer networks enable communication, resource sharing, remote access, data transfer and form the foundation of the Internet, allowing global connectivity and information exchange.

title: What is IPv4 and what are its classes?
subject: CN
answer: IPv4 is a 32-bit address system divided into four octets. It supports five classes: Class A (0.0.0.0–127.255.255.255), Class B (128.0.0.0–191.255.255.255), Class C (192.0.0.0–223.255.255.255), Class D for multicast and Class E for research.

title: Explain different network types (PAN, LAN, MAN, WAN, GAN)
subject: CN
answer: PAN connects devices around one person, LAN covers a building or office, MAN spans a city, WAN spans countries and GAN connects global networks using satellites such as the Internet.

title: What is LAN?
subject: CN
answer: A Local Area Network connects computers within a limited area such as a home or office, allowing resource sharing. It can be wired using cables or wireless using Wi-Fi.

title: What is VPN?
subject: CN
answer: A Virtual Private Network creates a secure encrypted tunnel over the internet, allowing remote users or offices to connect safely to a private network.

title: Advantages of VPN
subject: CN
answer: VPN enables secure remote access, reduces cost compared to dedicated WANs, protects data via encryption, hides IP identity and supports secure communication between branches.

title: Types of VPN
subject: CN
answer: Access VPN provides remote connectivity for individual users. Site-to-Site VPN connects entire office networks, including intranet VPN for internal access and extranet VPN for partner access.

title: What are nodes and links?
subject: CN
answer: Nodes are devices such as computers, printers or servers that communicate over a network. Links are communication paths (wired or wireless) connecting nodes.

title: What is network topology?
subject: CN
answer: Network topology is the physical or logical arrangement of devices and links in a network, defining how nodes are connected and communicate.

title: Explain different network topologies
subject: CN
answer: Bus uses a single backbone cable, Star connects all nodes to a central hub, Ring connects nodes circularly, Mesh provides multiple connections, Tree combines star + bus, and Hybrid mixes multiple topologies.

title: How are network types classified?
subject: CN
answer: Networks are classified based on coverage area such as PAN, LAN, MAN, WAN and GAN depending on geographic reach.

title: What are private and special IP addresses?
subject: CN
answer: Private IPs are reserved for internal networks (Class A: 10.0.0.0/8, Class B: 172.16.0.0/12, Class C: 192.168.0.0/16). Special addresses in 127.x.x.x are used for loopback and testing.

title: What is DNS?
subject: CN
answer: DNS translates human-readable domain names into IP addresses, acting like the Internet's phonebook. It typically uses port 53.

title: What is a router and how is it different from a gateway?
subject: CN
answer: A router connects multiple networks and forwards packets using IP addresses. A gateway can connect dissimilar networks and performs protocol translation in addition to routing.

title: What is SMTP?
subject: CN
answer: SMTP stands for Simple Mail Transfer Protocol. It defines how emails are sent between servers and supports end-to-end and store-and-forward communication. It listens on port 25.

title: What is the OSI reference model?
subject: CN
answer: The OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model is a conceptual networking framework with seven layers that standardizes communication between systems and devices.

title: Name the seven layers of the OSI model
subject: CN
answer: Physical, Data Link, Network, Transport, Session, Presentation, Application.

title: Explain the Physical Layer
subject: CN
answer: The Physical Layer transmits raw bits over communication media. It defines cables, connectors, voltages, bit rate and transmission modes such as simplex, half-duplex and full-duplex.

title: Explain the Data Link Layer
subject: CN
answer: The Data Link Layer converts raw communication into a reliable link. It performs framing, error detection using CRC and manages access to shared media using protocols like CSMA/CD, CSMA/CA and Token Passing.

title: Explain the Network Layer
subject: CN
answer: The Network Layer controls routing of packets between networks, assigns logical addressing, manages congestion and uses protocols like IP and ICMP.

title: Explain the Transport Layer
subject: CN
answer: The Transport Layer segments data, ensures ordered delivery and reliability, and reassembles packets at the receiver. It uses protocols like TCP and UDP.

title: Explain the Session Layer
subject: CN
answer: The Session Layer manages communication sessions between devices, establishes connections, synchronizes data and handles dialogue control.

title: Explain the Presentation Layer
subject: CN
answer: The Presentation Layer ensures proper data translation, encryption, compression and formatting between sender and receiver.

title: Explain the Application Layer
subject: CN
answer: The Application Layer provides services directly to users such as email, web browsing, file transfer and network management.

title: What is the TCP/IP model?
subject: CN
answer: The TCP/IP model is a four-layer model designed by the U.S. Department of Defense. It consists of Link, Internet, Transport and Application layers.

title: Name the four layers of TCP/IP
subject: CN
answer: Link Layer, Internet Layer, Transport Layer, Application Layer.

title: Difference between OSI model and TCP/IP model
subject: CN
answer: OSI has seven layers while TCP/IP has four. OSI is theoretical and protocol-independent, while TCP/IP is practical and protocol-oriented. TCP/IP is more flexible and widely used.

title: What is HTTP?
subject: CN
answer: HTTP is HyperText Transfer Protocol. It defines communication between web browsers and servers over the Web. It is stateless and uses port 80 by default.

title: What is HTTPS?
subject: CN
answer: HTTPS is HTTP Secure. It combines HTTP with SSL/TLS encryption to secure communication, ensure confidentiality and server authentication. It uses port 443.

title: What is FTP?
subject: CN
answer: FTP stands for File Transfer Protocol. It transfers files between systems reliably and efficiently and supports uploading and downloading.

title: What is TCP?
subject: CN
answer: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) is a reliable, connection-oriented protocol. It ensures ordered delivery, retransmits lost packets and uses three-way handshake to establish connections.

title: What is UDP?
subject: CN
answer: UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is a connectionless protocol that sends packets without acknowledgment, making it faster but less reliable. It is used in streaming and real-time communication.

title: Difference between TCP and UDP
subject: CN
answer: TCP is connection-oriented, reliable and slower. UDP is connectionless, unreliable but faster. TCP ensures packet order and uses acknowledgments, while UDP does not.

title: What is ICMP?
subject: CN
answer: ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol) is used for error handling and diagnostics in networks. It helps detect unreachable hosts, delays and connectivity issues.

title: What is DHCP?
subject: CN
answer: DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) automatically assigns IP addresses, subnet masks, gateways and DNS information to devices joining a network. It helps avoid manual configuration errors.

title: What is ARP?
subject: CN
answer: ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) maps a logical IP address to a physical MAC address so that devices in a local network can communicate.

title: What is a MAC address?
subject: CN
answer: A MAC address is a unique 48-bit or 64-bit hardware address assigned to a network interface card (NIC). It identifies a device physically on the network.

title: Difference between IP address and MAC address
subject: CN
answer: MAC address is a physical hardware address fixed to a NIC, while IP address is a logical address assigned by the network. MAC works at Data Link Layer while IP works at Network Layer.

title: What is a subnet?
subject: CN
answer: A subnet is a logically divided part of a network. Subnetting improves routing efficiency, security and reduces broadcast traffic.

title: What is a hub?
subject: CN
answer: A hub is a simple networking device working at the physical layer. It broadcasts incoming data to all ports and does not reduce collisions.

title: What is a switch?
subject: CN
answer: A switch operates at the data link layer. It forwards frames only to the destination MAC address, reducing collisions and improving efficiency.

title: Difference between hub and switch
subject: CN
answer: A hub broadcasts data to all devices and works at the physical layer. A switch forwards data intelligently based on MAC addresses and works at the data link layer.

title: What is a firewall?
subject: CN
answer: A firewall filters incoming and outgoing network traffic based on rules. It protects private networks from unauthorized access and attacks.

title: What is unicasting?
subject: CN
answer: Unicasting is communication where data is sent from one sender to one specific receiver.

title: What is multicasting?
subject: CN
answer: Multicasting sends data from one sender to a selected group of receivers, commonly used in online streaming and conferencing.

title: What is broadcasting?
subject: CN
answer: Broadcasting sends data from one sender to all devices on a network. Protocols like ARP and DHCP use broadcasting.

title: What is anycasting?
subject: CN
answer: Anycasting allows data to be sent from one sender to the nearest or best-performing device from a group of servers, commonly used in CDNs.

title: What is DNS?
subject: CN
answer: DNS (Domain Name System) translates human-readable domain names like google.com into IP addresses. It works using port 53.

title: What happens when you type google.com in a browser?
subject: CN
answer: 1) Browser checks cache. 2) DNS resolves domain to IP. 3) TCP connection established using three-way handshake. 4) HTTP/HTTPS request sent. 5) Server processes request and responds. 6) Browser renders content and may reuse the connection.

title: What is FTP used for?
subject: CN
answer: FTP is used for transferring files between computers over a network. It supports uploading and downloading.

title: What is a router?
subject: CN
answer: A router connects multiple networks and forwards packets based on IP addresses. It operates at the network layer.

title: What is a gateway?
subject: CN
answer: A gateway connects different types of networks and can translate protocols, while routers connect similar networks.

title: What is ICMP used for?
subject: CN
answer: ICMP is used by routers and hosts to report errors, unreachable destinations and network diagnostics such as ping.

title: What is NAT?
subject: CN
answer: NAT (Network Address Translation) converts private IP addresses to public IPs so multiple devices can access the internet using a single public IP.

title: What is latency?
subject: CN
answer: Latency is the total time taken for a data packet to travel from source to destination. It includes propagation delay, transmission delay, processing delay and queuing delay.

title: What is bandwidth?
subject: CN
answer: Bandwidth is the maximum rate at which data can be transferred over a network connection, usually measured in Mbps or Gbps.

title: What is throughput?
subject: CN
answer: Throughput is the actual amount of data successfully delivered over a network in a given time. It is usually lower than bandwidth due to overhead and network congestion.

title: What is jitter?
subject: CN
answer: Jitter is the variation in packet arrival times. High jitter affects real-time applications like VoIP, gaming and video calls.

title: What is congestion in networks?
subject: CN
answer: Network congestion happens when too many packets are present in the network causing delay, packet drops, timeouts and retransmissions.

title: What is QoS?
subject: CN
answer: QoS (Quality of Service) prioritizes network traffic to guarantee performance for important services such as VoIP, video streaming and critical applications.

title: What is subnet mask?
subject: CN
answer: A subnet mask separates the network portion and host portion of an IP address. Example: 255.255.255.0 indicates first 24 bits are network.

title: What is default gateway?
subject: CN
answer: A default gateway is a router that forwards traffic from a local network to external networks when no other route is available.

title: What is traceroute?
subject: CN
answer: Traceroute is a diagnostic tool that shows the path packets take to reach a destination and measures delays across each hop.

title: What is ping?
subject: CN
answer: Ping uses ICMP echo request and reply messages to test connectivity and measure round-trip time between two devices.

title: What is proxy server?
subject: CN
answer: A proxy server acts as an intermediary between client and server, providing security, caching and anonymity.

title: What is load balancing?
subject: CN
answer: Load balancing distributes incoming network traffic across multiple servers to improve performance, reliability and availability.

title: What is packet sniffing?
subject: CN
answer: Packet sniffing is monitoring and capturing network packets using tools like Wireshark. It is used for troubleshooting and security analysis.

title: What is spoofing?
subject: CN
answer: Spoofing is disguising communication by falsifying sender identity—such as IP spoofing, email spoofing or ARP spoofing—to mislead receivers.

title: What is VPN tunneling?
subject: CN
answer: VPN tunneling encapsulates data packets inside encrypted packets so they can securely travel across public networks.

title: What is port forwarding?
subject: CN
answer: Port forwarding maps external network traffic to internal private IP addresses and ports, enabling remote access to internal services.

title: What is symmetric and asymmetric encryption?
subject: CN
answer: Symmetric encryption uses one key for encryption and decryption, while asymmetric uses public and private keys. HTTPS uses both.

title: What is packet fragmentation?
subject: CN
answer: Fragmentation occurs when large packets are split into smaller units to match the network's Maximum Transmission Unit (MTU).

title: What is MTU?
subject: CN
answer: MTU (Maximum Transmission Unit) is the largest size of a packet that can be transmitted over a network without fragmentation.

title: What is a collision domain?
subject: CN
answer: A collision domain is a network segment where data packets may collide when transmitted simultaneously. Switches reduce collision domains while hubs do not.

title: What is a broadcast domain?
subject: CN
answer: A broadcast domain is a logical network segment where a broadcast packet is received by all devices. Routers separate broadcast domains; switches do not by default.

title: What is VLAN?
subject: CN
answer: A VLAN (Virtual LAN) logically divides a physical network into multiple isolated networks, improving security and reducing broadcast traffic.

title: What is NAT?
subject: CN
answer: NAT (Network Address Translation) translates private IP addresses to public IP addresses, allowing multiple devices to share one public IP.

title: Difference between static and dynamic IP?
subject: CN
answer: A static IP does not change and is manually assigned. A dynamic IP is automatically assigned by DHCP and may change over time.

title: What is IPv6 and why do we need it?
subject: CN
answer: IPv6 is a 128-bit addressing scheme designed to replace IPv4 due to address exhaustion. It supports more devices, security and improved routing.

title: What is tunneling in IPv6?
subject: CN
answer: IPv6 tunneling encapsulates IPv6 packets inside IPv4 packets so IPv6 networks can communicate over IPv4 infrastructure.

title: What is HTTP persistent connection?
subject: CN
answer: In persistent HTTP, a single TCP connection is reused for multiple requests and responses, reducing latency and overhead.

title: What is SSL/TLS?
subject: CN
answer: SSL/TLS encrypts communication between client and server, providing confidentiality, authentication and integrity in HTTPS.

title: What is DNS caching?
subject: CN
answer: DNS caching stores previously resolved domain names locally to speed up future lookups and reduce DNS traffic.

title: What is DHCP lease?
subject: CN
answer: A DHCP lease is the time period for which a device is allowed to use an assigned IP address before renewal is required.

title: What is network redundancy?
subject: CN
answer: Network redundancy means adding alternate paths, devices or links to ensure connectivity continues if one path fails.

title: What is a DMZ in networking?
subject: CN
answer: A DMZ (Demilitarized Zone) is a separate network segment exposed to external users while keeping the internal network protected.

title: What is intrusion detection system (IDS)?
subject: CN
answer: IDS monitors network traffic for suspicious activity and alerts administrators when potential attacks are detected.

title: What is intrusion prevention system (IPS)?
subject: CN
answer: IPS detects malicious activity like IDS but also automatically blocks or mitigates threats in real time.

title: What is port scanning?
subject: CN
answer: Port scanning is probing network ports to discover open or vulnerable services. Tools include Nmap. It is used in security testing and attacks.

title: What is DNS spoofing?
subject: CN
answer: DNS spoofing is an attack where fake DNS responses redirect users to malicious websites instead of legitimate ones.

title: What is packet filtering firewall?
subject: CN
answer: A packet filtering firewall allows or blocks packets based on IP address, port number and protocol without inspecting content.

title: What is stateful firewall?
subject: CN
answer: A stateful firewall tracks active connections and makes filtering decisions based on connection state, improving security over simple packet filters.

title: What is network virtualization?
subject: CN
answer: Network virtualization creates logical network environments on top of physical infrastructure, enabling isolation, automation and scalability.

title: What is cloud networking?
subject: CN
answer: Cloud networking uses cloud-based infrastructure to host, manage and deliver network services such as routing, firewalls, load balancing and VPN.
